name: Self-Portraiture: Identity and Representation
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: use a range of techniques to record their observations in visual journals
use a range of techniques and media, including painting
pedagogical_rationale: Self-portraiture is a powerful vehicle for KS3 identity exploration through art. Pupils learn proportional drawing of the face (the eyes are halfway down the head, not at the top), tonal rendering of three-dimensional form, and the difference between likeness and character. Studying self-portraits from Rembrandt to Frida Kahlo to contemporary selfie culture connects art history to pupils' own experience. The unit naturally integrates observational drawing, painting technique, and critical analysis of how artists have represented identity.
common_pitfalls: Eyes placed too high on the head -- teach the skull proportions before starting
Flat, outline-based faces with no tonal modelling -- use directional lighting to make shadows visible
Avoiding personal expression by copying photographs mechanically -- set constraints that push beyond likeness (e.g. express a mood, use only two colours)

name: Pop Art: Mass Culture and Visual Communication
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: about the history of art, craft, design and architecture, including periods, styles and major movements from ancient times to the present day
use a range of techniques and media, including painting
pedagogical_rationale: Pop Art (Warhol, Lichtenstein, Hamilton) is the ideal movement for teaching KS3 pupils about the relationship between art and mass culture. The bold colours, graphic techniques, and appropriation of commercial imagery are visually engaging and technically accessible. Screen printing or lino printing from Pop Art source material teaches printmaking technique. The critical questions -- Is a soup can art? Who decides? -- introduce pupils to the contested nature of art and its boundaries, which is central to KS3 art history.
common_pitfalls: Copying Warhol prints without understanding the conceptual challenge Pop Art posed -- discuss why everyday objects were provocative as art
Using too many colours in screen prints -- limit to 3-4 bold colours for impact
Treating it as 'easy art' -- the apparent simplicity of Pop Art disguises sophisticated compositional and colour decisions

name: Sculpture and Installation: 3D Form and Space
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: use a range of techniques and media, including painting
increase their proficiency in the handling of different materials
pedagogical_rationale: Three-dimensional work at KS3 moves beyond the clay modelling of primary school to address sculpture as a discipline with its own language of form, space, mass and void. Pupils learn to construct with wire, mod-roc, cardboard, and found materials, developing skills that primary did not cover. Studying Hepworth, Giacometti, and contemporary installation artists (Cornelia Parker, Phyllida Barlow) teaches that sculpture occupies and transforms space. The unit develops spatial reasoning, structural problem-solving, and understanding of how viewpoint changes the perception of three-dimensional work.
common_pitfalls: Building structures that collapse -- teach internal armature construction before external form
Only considering the front view -- require pupils to photograph and evaluate from multiple angles
Wire sculpture too flimsy -- demonstrate twisting and binding techniques for structural integrity

name: Printmaking: Reduction Lino and Multi-Layer Prints
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: use a range of techniques and media, including painting
increase their proficiency in the handling of different materials
pedagogical_rationale: Reduction lino printing is one of the most satisfying and technically demanding printmaking processes accessible at KS3. Pupils print an edition, then cut away more of the block and print a second colour on top, building up layers. This teaches colour theory (how overlapping colours interact), planning (the process is irreversible -- each cut is permanent), and the discipline of registration. The technique connects to Hokusai (KS2) and extends to Expressionist woodcuts (Kirchner, Munch) for art history context.
common_pitfalls: Cutting away too much in early layers -- plan the whole sequence of cuts before starting
Poor registration between layers -- use a jig or registration marks from the first print
Safety with lino cutters -- always cut away from the body; use bench hooks; heat the lino for easier cutting

name: Street Art and Graffiti Culture
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: about the history of art, craft, design and architecture, including periods, styles and major movements from ancient times to the present day
analyse and evaluate their own work, and that of others, in order to strengthen the visual impact or applications of their work
pedagogical_rationale: Street art (Banksy, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Shepard Fairey) engages pupils who may not identify with traditional gallery art. The unit raises critical questions about art, ownership, public space, and the boundary between art and vandalism. Technically, it teaches stencil making, spray paint control, and large-scale composition. The strong graphic style develops understanding of visual impact and how art communicates in public contexts. This is often the unit that changes pupils' relationship with art as a subject.
common_pitfalls: Glorifying vandalism -- discuss the legal and ethical dimensions openly; distinguish commissioned murals from illegal graffiti
Stencils too complex to cut accurately -- start with bold, simple silhouettes
Spray paint health and safety -- always use in well-ventilated areas with masks; consider spray-free alternatives (sponge daubing)

name: Photography and Digital Manipulation
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: use a range of techniques and media, including painting
analyse and evaluate their own work, and that of others, in order to strengthen the visual impact or applications of their work
pedagogical_rationale: Photography is a core KS3 medium that connects to GCSE Photography endorsement pathways. Pupils learn that photography is not just pointing and shooting but involves deliberate compositional decisions: rule of thirds, depth of field, framing, viewpoint, and lighting. Digital manipulation (Photoshop or free alternatives) teaches that the camera is a starting point, not an endpoint. Studying photographers from Man Ray to Cindy Sherman to contemporary documentary photography develops critical understanding of how photographic images construct meaning.
common_pitfalls: Taking hundreds of random photographs rather than composing deliberately -- set a limit (e.g. 12 shots) to force planning
Over-relying on digital filters rather than learning manual adjustments -- teach the principles behind each tool
Treating photography as separate from 'real art' -- place it alongside painting and sculpture in the critical framework

name: Graphic Design and Typography
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: about the history of art, craft, design and architecture, including periods, styles and major movements from ancient times to the present day
increase their proficiency in the handling of different materials
pedagogical_rationale: Graphic design teaches that art serves communicative purposes beyond self-expression. Pupils learn how typography, layout, colour and image work together to communicate messages to specific audiences. Studying designers from the Bauhaus (Moholy-Nagy, Herbert Bayer) through to contemporary branding teaches that design is a discipline with its own history and conventions. The unit prepares for GCSE Graphic Communication endorsement and connects art to the designed world pupils inhabit.
common_pitfalls: Using too many fonts -- limit to 2 maximum per design to teach typographic discipline
Ignoring hierarchy -- teach pupils that the viewer's eye must be guided through the design in a specific order
Digital-only work -- start with hand-drawn lettering and manual layouts before moving to software

name: Textile Art and Surface Design
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: use a range of techniques and media, including painting
increase their proficiency in the handling of different materials
pedagogical_rationale: Textile art bridges art and craft, challenging the hierarchy that privileges painting over making. Pupils learn fabric manipulation techniques (batik, applique, embroidery, screen printing on fabric) that develop fine motor control and patience. Studying textile artists from William Morris through to contemporary fibre art (Grayson Perry, Faith Ringgold) teaches that textiles carry meaning and tell stories. The unit prepares for GCSE Textile Design endorsement and develops material handling skills distinct from painting and drawing.
common_pitfalls: Batik wax too cool to penetrate fabric -- test temperature on scrap fabric first
Embroidery stitches too tight, puckering the fabric -- teach even tension through practice
Designs too detailed for the medium -- textile techniques require bold, simplified forms

name: Critical Study: Art Movements Timeline
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: about the history of art, craft, design and architecture, including periods, styles and major movements from ancient times to the present day
analyse and evaluate their own work, and that of others, in order to strengthen the visual impact or applications of their work
pedagogical_rationale: A structured chronological study of major art movements (Renaissance, Baroque, Romanticism, Impressionism, Expressionism, Cubism, Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Contemporary) gives pupils the historical framework the NC requires. Each movement is studied through one or two exemplary artists and key works, with pupils producing both analytical writing and practical responses. This is the backbone unit for KS3 art history, ensuring pupils leave KS3 with a coherent mental timeline of how art has developed.
common_pitfalls: Covering too many movements superficially -- focus on 6-8 key movements with genuine depth
Only Western movements -- include Islamic art, Japanese art, African art as parallel traditions
Treating it as purely theoretical -- each movement studied must include a practical making response

name: Personal Project: Developing a Creative Voice
subject: Art and Design
curriculum_reference: use a range of techniques to record their observations in visual journals
analyse and evaluate their own work, and that of others, in order to strengthen the visual impact or applications of their work
pedagogical_rationale: The Y9 personal project is the culminating KS3 experience and the bridge to GCSE. Pupils choose their own theme, research relevant artists, experiment with materials, and produce a resolved outcome supported by a visual journal. This develops the independent creative decision-making, self-evaluation, and sustained project management skills that GCSE demands. The teacher's role shifts from instructor to mentor, guiding pupils through the creative process rather than directing the outcome.
common_pitfalls: Theme too broad ('nature', 'emotions') -- teach pupils to narrow and focus: what specific aspect? what angle?
Jumping to final piece without development work -- require documented experimentation in the visual journal
Pupils choosing only their strongest medium -- encourage at least one unfamiliar technique or material
